meta.title: Moby Dick: The Adventure
meta.author: Interactive Adaptation
meta.description: An epic interactive adventure based on Herman Melville's masterpiece. Navigate the treacherous waters of 1840s whaling, forge alliances, and face the legendary White Whale.

manhattan_streets.name: Manhattan Streets
manhattan_streets.description: The bustling streets of Manhattan, 1840s. Horse-drawn carriages clatter past brick buildings. The smell of the harbor drifts from the south.

exits.description: The docks lie to the south

manhattan_docks.name: Manhattan Docks
manhattan_docks.description: Wooden piers stretch into the harbor. Ships of all sizes bob at anchor. The packet boat to New Bedford awaits passengers.

packet_boat.name: Packet Boat
packet_boat.description: A sturdy coastal vessel making the run between Manhattan and New Bedford.

new_bedford_streets.name: New Bedford Streets
new_bedford_streets.description: The prosperous streets of New Bedford, the whaling capital of the world. Fine mansions built on whale oil money line the avenues.

spouter_inn.name: The Spouter Inn
spouter_inn.description: Peter Coffin's inn. A dark, low-ceilinged establishment filled with the smell of whale oil and tobacco. A mysterious painting hangs on the wall.

whalemans_chapel.name: Whaleman's Chapel
whalemans_chapel.description: A solemn chapel where whalemen pray before voyages. Memorial tablets line the walls, each recording a sailor lost at sea. Father Mapple's famous pulpit shaped like a ship's bow dominates the front.

new_bedford_shops.name: New Bedford Shops
new_bedford_shops.description: A row of shops catering to whalemen. A chandlery sells supplies, and a general store offers various goods.

new_bedford_docks.name: New Bedford Docks
new_bedford_docks.description: The busy wharves of New Bedford. Whale ships being outfitted for long voyages fill every berth. The ferry to Nantucket departs from here.

nantucket_streets.name: Nantucket Streets
nantucket_streets.description: The sandy streets of Nantucket island, the original whaling capital. The salty wind carries tales of the sea.

try_pots_inn.name: The Try Pots Inn
try_pots_inn.description: Mrs. Hussey's inn, famous for its chowder. Two enormous black pots stand outside like gateposts.

nantucket_docks.name: Nantucket Docks
nantucket_docks.description: The weathered docks of Nantucket. The Pequod sits among other vessels, her ancient hull decorated with whale teeth and bones.

pequod_deck.name: The Pequod - Main Deck
pequod_deck.description: The main deck of the whaling ship Pequod. Whale bone decorations are set into her ancient timbers. The masts reach toward the sky.

pequod_below.name: The Pequod - Below Decks
pequod_below.description: The cramped quarters below deck. Hammocks hang in rows. The smell of tar, hemp, and old whale oil is overpowering.

pequod_quarterdeck.name: The Pequod - Quarterdeck
pequod_quarterdeck.description: The quarterdeck where Captain Ahab paces on his ivory leg. From here, the entire ship and the vast ocean are visible.

open_ocean.name: The Open Ocean
open_ocean.description: Endless blue water stretches to every horizon. The Pequod cuts through the waves on her relentless hunt.

crows_nest.name: The Crow's Nest
crows_nest.description: High atop the mainmast, the crow's nest sways with the ship. The view is breathtaking — ocean in every direction.

whaleboat.name: The Whaleboat
whaleboat.description: A small cedar whaleboat, lowered from the Pequod to chase whales. It rocks dangerously on the waves.

moby_dick_waters.name: Moby Dick's Waters
moby_dick_waters.description: The waters where the White Whale has been sighted. The sea seems alive with menace. Every wave could hide the beast.

peter_coffin.name: Peter Coffin
peter_coffin.description: The landlord of the Spouter Inn. A friendly but shrewd man who knows every sailor passing through New Bedford.

queequeg.name: Queequeg
queequeg.description: A Polynesian harpooner from the island of Rokovoko. Covered in ritual tattoos, he carries a tomahawk-pipe and worships his idol Yojo. Despite his fearsome appearance, he is noble and kind-hearted.

father_mapple.name: Father Mapple
father_mapple.description: A former whaleman turned preacher. He delivers passionate sermons from a pulpit shaped like a ship's bow.

ahab.name: Captain Ahab
ahab.description: The obsessed captain of the Pequod. He lost his leg to Moby Dick and has sworn vengeance. His ivory leg thumps on the deck as he paces.

starbuck.name: Starbuck
starbuck.description: The Pequod's first mate. A tall, thin Nantucketer. Brave but cautious, deeply religious, and increasingly troubled by Ahab's obsession.

stubb.name: Stubb
stubb.description: The second mate. An easy-going Cape Cod man who smokes his pipe constantly and faces danger with cheerful humor.

flask.name: Flask
flask.description: The third mate. Short, stout, and pugnacious. He views whales as personal enemies and hunts them with fierce determination.

mrs_hussey.name: Mrs. Hussey
mrs_hussey.description: The proprietor of the Try Pots Inn on Nantucket. Famous for her clam and cod chowder.

shopkeeper.name: Shopkeeper
shopkeeper.description: A weathered old chandler who sells supplies to whalemen. Knows every ship in the fleet.

elijah.name: Elijah
elijah.description: A mysterious stranger on the Nantucket docks who delivers cryptic warnings about Captain Ahab and the Pequod.

sea_bag.name: Sea Bag
sea_bag.description: Your sturdy canvas sea bag, containing your worldly possessions.

packet_ticket.name: Packet Boat Ticket
packet_ticket.description: A ticket for passage from Manhattan to New Bedford. Cost: 200 cents.

ferry_ticket.name: Ferry Ticket to Nantucket
ferry_ticket.description: Passage on the ferry from New Bedford to Nantucket island. Cost: 150 cents.

harpoon.name: Harpoon
harpoon.description: A well-balanced whaling harpoon. Essential for the hunt.

spyglass.name: Spyglass
spyglass.description: A brass telescope for spotting whales from the crow's nest. Cost: 300 cents.

whaling_knife.name: Whaling Knife
whaling_knife.description: A sharp knife used for flensing whales. Also handy in a tight spot. Cost: 100 cents.

warm_coat.name: Warm Coat
warm_coat.description: A heavy wool coat to ward off the bitter ocean cold. Cost: 200 cents.

queequeg_idol.name: Yojo (Queequeg's Idol)
queequeg_idol.description: Queequeg's small black wooden idol. He has entrusted it to you as a sign of friendship.

doubloon.name: Ahab's Gold Doubloon
doubloon.description: The Spanish gold doubloon Ahab nailed to the mainmast as reward for whoever first spots Moby Dick.

compass.name: Compass
compass.description: A brass mariner's compass. Essential for navigation. Cost: 250 cents.

rope.name: Coil of Rope
rope.description: A strong hemp rope, useful for many situations aboard ship. Cost: 75 cents.

medical_kit.name: Medical Kit
medical_kit.description: A small kit with bandages and basic medical supplies. Cost: 150 cents.

whale_chart.name: Whale Migration Chart
whale_chart.description: A detailed chart showing whale migration routes. Found in the Pequod's cabin.

starbuck_letter.name: Starbuck's Letter
starbuck_letter.description: A letter from Starbuck to his wife, entrusted to you in case the worst should happen.

ship_log.name: Ship's Log
ship_log.description: The Pequod's official log book, containing records of the voyage.

survival_rations.name: Survival Rations
survival_rations.description: Hardtack and dried beef. Not delicious, but could save your life.

mysterious_painting.name: Mysterious Painting
mysterious_painting.description: A dark, smoke-stained oil painting. It seems to depict a whale destroying a ship, but the layers of grime make it hard to tell.

memorial_tablets.name: Memorial Tablets
memorial_tablets.description: Stone and wooden tablets commemorating whalemen lost at sea. Each tells a brief, tragic story.

pulpit.name: Ship's Bow Pulpit
pulpit.description: Father Mapple's famous pulpit, built to resemble the bow of a ship. He climbs a rope ladder to reach it.

manhattan_start.title: Call Me Ishmael
manhattan_start.content:
Whenever I find myself growing grim about the mouth; whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul — then, I account it high time to get to sea as soon as I can. With nothing particular to interest me on shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part of the world.

The streets of Manhattan bustle around you. You have $5.00 in your pocket and a restless spirit. The sea calls.

interactions.resultText: You wander through the crowded streets. Merchants hawk their wares, carriages rattle past, and the smell of the harbor grows stronger as you walk south. Your feet naturally carry you toward the water.
You make your way south through the cobblestone streets toward the waterfront.

manhattan_docks_arrive.title: The Waterfront
manhattan_docks_arrive.content:
The Manhattan docks stretch before you, alive with commerce. Ships from around the world sit at anchor. A sign advertises the packet boat to New Bedford — the great whaling port.

A ticket costs $2.00. You'll need one to begin your whaling career.

interactions.resultText: You hand over two dollars and receive a ticket for the New Bedford packet. The boat departs within the hour.

Tall-masted vessels from every seafaring nation crowd the harbor. Merchantmen, clippers, and the occasional man-of-war. But it's the rugged whaleships that catch your eye — battered veterans of the Pacific, their hulls dark with age and whale oil.

interactions.buttonText: Board the packet boat to New Bedford
interactions.resultText: You show your ticket and board the sturdy coastal vessel. As Manhattan shrinks behind you, excitement builds. Your whaling adventure begins!

interactions.buttonText: Head back to the Manhattan streets
interactions.resultText: You turn away from the docks and walk back into the bustle of Manhattan. The city thrums around you — carriages, vendors, the smell of roasting chestnuts.

packet_journey.title: Passage to New Bedford
packet_journey.content:
The packet boat rocks gently as it makes its way along the coast. Salt spray mists your face. Other passengers huddle against the cold — a farmer, two merchants, and an old sailor who eyes you knowingly.

The old sailor strikes up conversation about the whaling trade.

interactions.resultText: "Heading to New Bedford, eh? Going a-whaling?" The old man's eyes glitter. "Best stay at the Spouter Inn — Peter Coffin's place. Cheap and honest. And if I were you, I'd make for Nantucket after that. That's where the real whalemen sign on." He leans close. "But beware the Pequod, lad. There's stories about that ship's captain..."
You find a sheltered spot and doze off. The rocking of the boat is oddly comforting. You dream of great whales and vast oceans.

The packet boat rounds the point and New Bedford comes into view — a prosperous town built on whale oil money. Grand houses line the hills above the waterfront. This is the whaling capital of the world.

new_bedford_arrival.title: New Bedford
new_bedford_arrival.content:
New Bedford sprawls before you in the cold November evening. The streets are paved with whale oil money — fine mansions, well-stocked shops, and everywhere the signs of the whaling industry.

You need lodging for the night, and you should start preparing for your whaling voyage. There's much to see and do here.

interactions.resultText: You make your way to Peter Coffin's establishment, the Spouter Inn.
You follow the sound of hymns to the famous Whaleman's Chapel.
You head to the chandlery district to look at supplies.
You walk down to the bustling waterfront.

spouter_inn_arrive.title: The Spouter Inn
spouter_inn_arrive.content:
You push open the heavy door of the Spouter Inn. The interior is dark and low-ceilinged, lit by whale oil lamps. The air is thick with tobacco smoke and the smell of burning oil.

A large, smoky painting hangs on the wall — impossible to make out in the dim light. Peter Coffin, the landlord, stands behind the bar polishing a glass.

interactions.resultText: You peer at the painting through layers of smoke and grime. Gradually a scene emerges: a ship caught in a terrible storm, and rising from the waves, an enormous whale — white as a ghost. The painting fills you with an inexplicable dread.

"Evening, friend! Looking for a room?" Peter Coffin sizes you up with a practiced eye. "I've got one bed left, but you'll have to share with a harpooner. Don't worry — he's out selling embalmed heads at the moment. Peculiar fellow, but harmless. Room's 50 cents for the night."
You hand over fifty cents. Coffin leads you to a small room with a single large bed. "Your roommate will be along later. Name's Queequeg." The name means nothing to you — yet.

interactions.buttonText: Refuse — find somewhere else to sleep
interactions.resultText: Share a bed with a stranger? A harpooner who sells embalmed heads? You'd rather take your chances elsewhere.
You step back out into the cold New Bedford evening.

interactions.buttonText: Wipe the grime off the mysterious painting
interactions.resultText: You rub years of soot and whale oil from the canvas. The image emerges: a ship in a storm, a great leviathan rising from the waves, sailors tumbling into the sea. It's crude but powerful — painted by someone who had been there, who had seen the horror and survived to capture it in pigment.

Now that the painting is clean, you notice details: the whale has a wrinkled, white brow. The ship bears the name "Essex" on its stern. In the corner, a scratched inscription reads: "G. Pollard, 1822." This painting depicts the Essex disaster — a whale sinking a ship. A warning, perhaps, to all who enter this inn dreaming of whaling glory.

sleep_rough.title: A Cold Night
sleep_rough.content:
You try to sleep on a bench near the docks, but the November cold is merciless. Your teeth chatter, your bones ache. By midnight you're thoroughly miserable.

Perhaps sharing a bed with a harpooner isn't so bad after all.

interactions.buttonText: Give up and go to the Spouter Inn
interactions.resultText: Shivering and humbled, you trudge back to the inn. Peter Coffin smirks as you walk in.
Through sheer stubbornness, you survive the night. But you're exhausted, half-frozen, and hungry. Not the best start to your whaling career.

wait_for_queequeg.title: The Harpooner
wait_for_queequeg.content:
You're half asleep when the door bursts open. A towering figure enters, covered head to toe in dark tattoos, carrying a tomahawk in one hand and a shrunken head in the other. This must be Queequeg.

He doesn't notice you at first. He lights a small fire and begins praying to a tiny black idol — his god, Yojo.

interactions.resultText: "LANDLORD! Save me!" You shriek in terror. Peter Coffin rushes in. Queequeg looks bewildered. After much explanation and gesturing, the situation calms down. Not the best first impression.

You take a deep breath and speak up. "Good evening. I'm Ishmael — your bedfellow, it seems." Queequeg turns, surprised, then breaks into a broad grin. He offers you his tomahawk-pipe to smoke. You accept. Despite everything, you feel an instant kinship with this strange, noble savage.

You squeeze your eyes shut and try not to breathe. Queequeg finishes his ritual, extinguishes his fire, and climbs into bed beside you. His massive arm drapes over you like a bridge. It's going to be a long night.

queequeg_morning.title: A Bosom Friend
queequeg_morning.content:
Morning light filters into the room. Queequeg is already awake, carefully shaving with his harpoon's edge. In the daylight, you can see him more clearly — magnificent tattoos cover every inch of his dark skin, and despite his fearsome appearance, his eyes are gentle.

He turns to you and speaks in broken English: "You — good man. Queequeg see it. We be friends, yes? In my country, we share pipe, we brothers."

interactions.resultText: You and Queequeg smoke the tomahawk-pipe together, sealing your bond. He presses his forehead to yours in the manner of his people. From this moment, you are brothers. Queequeg takes out his small black idol, Yojo, and hands it to you. "Yojo say — you keep. For good luck."
You thank Queequeg for his hospitality but maintain a cautious reserve. He looks slightly disappointed but nods understandingly. He's a good fellow, you think — perhaps too good for the likes of you.

breakfast_spouter.title: Breakfast at the Spouter Inn
breakfast_spouter.content:
Downstairs, a hearty breakfast awaits — salt fish, hard bread, and strong coffee. Around the table sit weathered whalemen, each bearing the marks of their dangerous trade. The talk is all of ships, whales, and far-off seas.

You have several things to do in New Bedford before heading to Nantucket to find a ship.

interactions.resultText: The salt fish is surprisingly good, and the coffee warms you to the bone. You feel ready to face the day.
You step out into the cold morning air and head for the chapel.
You head to the chandlery to outfit yourself for the voyage.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the docks for the Nantucket ferry
interactions.resultText: Time to move on to Nantucket, where the real whaling ships are.

interactions.buttonText: Tell the other guests about Father Mapple's sermon
interactions.resultText: Over hardtack and coffee, you recount Father Mapple's powerful sermon to the assembled sailors. Several nod grimly — they've heard the old preacher before. "Aye," says one grizzled man. "Mapple knows the sea. He was a harpooner before he found God. Listen to his words, boy. The sea don't care about your plans."

chapel_visit.title: The Whaleman's Chapel
chapel_visit.content:
The chapel is hushed and solemn. Along the walls hang marble tablets — memorials to whalemen lost at sea. Each tells a brief, terrible story:

"SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF JOHN TALBOT, Who, at the age of eighteen, was lost overboard near the Isle of Desolation."

Father Mapple, a towering old man who was once a harpooner himself, climbs a rope ladder to his pulpit — shaped like the bow of a whale ship — and begins his sermon.

interactions.resultText: You read tablet after tablet, each recording a life swallowed by the sea. Young men, old men, entire boat crews — all lost to the whale fishery. The weight of mortality settles on your shoulders. Is this what awaits you?

Father Mapple's voice thunders through the chapel as he tells the story of Jonah and the Whale. "Delight is to him whose strong arms yet support him, when the ship of this base treacherous world has gone down beneath him!" His words pierce something deep within you. The sea is dangerous, but there is glory in facing it honestly.

interactions.buttonText: Speak with Father Mapple after the sermon
interactions.resultText: The old preacher regards you with kind eyes. "Going to sea, are you, lad? Remember — truth is the hardest thing to face, harder than any whale. Keep your soul honest, and the Lord will guide your harpoon." He places a weathered hand on your shoulder.
You step back into the daylight, the sermon still ringing in your ears.

interactions.buttonText: Brush the dust from the memorial tablets
interactions.resultText: You carefully brush decades of dust from the marble tablets. Names emerge, sharp and clear. "Sacred to the memory of Robert Long, who perished in the Pacific, 1830." "John Talbot, killed by a sperm whale off the coast of Japan." Dozens of names. Dozens of widows. Dozens of children who never saw their fathers again. The weight of it settles in your chest.

shops_visit.title: Outfitting for the Voyage
shops_visit.content:
The chandlery is crammed with supplies for whalemen. Harpoons, ropes, knives, compasses, spyglasses, clothing — everything a man needs to survive months at sea.

The shopkeeper, a weathered old chandler, eyes you appraisingly. "Fitting out for a voyage, are ye?"

interactions.resultText: You select a fine steel blade with a bone handle. "Good choice," the shopkeeper nods. "Sharp enough to cut blubber — or save your life."
A heavy wool pea coat, well-suited for the bitter ocean winds. You'll be grateful for this in the southern seas.
A fine brass telescope. You extend it and peer through — the world leaps into focus. This will be invaluable for spotting whales from the masthead.
A sturdy brass compass that sits perfectly in your palm. The needle swings to north with satisfying precision.
Good strong hemp rope, fifty fathoms of it. A sailor can never have too much rope.
A small leather case containing bandages, salves, and laudanum. The shopkeeper nods approvingly. "Smart lad. Most don't think of this until it's too late."

"If you're going whaling, you'll want at minimum a good knife and warm clothing. A spyglass will get you noticed by the captain — masthead watches are important. And..." he lowers his voice, "...if you end up on the Pequod, watch yourself. Captain Ahab ain't right in the head since that white whale took his leg."
You head back to the main streets of New Bedford.

"Credit?" The shopkeeper laughs, then sees your face. "Boy, I've given credit to a hundred sailors. Know how many paid me back? Three. Three out of a hundred. The rest are at the bottom of the ocean, and their debts with 'em." He pauses. "Tell you what — work my stockroom for an hour, and I'll give you a knife at half price. Call it an investment in your survival."

nb_docks_visit.title: New Bedford Waterfront
nb_docks_visit.content:
The New Bedford docks are alive with activity. Whale ships are being outfitted, barrels of supplies rolled aboard, and crews mustering. The ferry to Nantucket sits at the far end of the wharf.

A ferry ticket costs $1.50.

interactions.buttonText: Buy a ferry ticket to Nantucket ($1.50)
interactions.resultText: You purchase passage to Nantucket. The ferry departs shortly.

interactions.buttonText: Help load cargo to earn money
interactions.resultText: You spend several hours hauling barrels and coils of rope aboard a merchant vessel. It's backbreaking work, but the foreman pays you fairly. "You've got a strong back, lad. Good for whaling."
You show your ticket and board the Nantucket ferry. Queequeg is already aboard, his harpoon bundled at his side. The wind is brisk as you pull away from the New Bedford shore.

interactions.buttonText: Board the ferry to Nantucket (not ready)
interactions.resultText: The ferry captain looks you over. "Going to Nantucket alone, are ye? No harpooner, no companion? No captain will take on a lone greenhand. Find yourself a partner first — try the Spouter Inn, there's always whalemen looking for a berth."

interactions.buttonText: Board the ferry to Nantucket (not ready)
interactions.resultText: A grizzled sailor at the gangway stops you. "Where's your blade, lad? You can't go whaling without even a knife. No captain would sign you on looking like that. Get yourself outfitted at the chandlery first — a knife at minimum."
You head back into town.

nantucket_ferry.title: Crossing to Nantucket
nantucket_ferry.content:
The ferry churns through the choppy waters of Nantucket Sound. Nantucket island appears on the horizon — a low sandy strip barely rising from the sea. This island sent out the first whaling fleets and still births the finest whalemen in the world.

Queequeg stands at the bow, unfazed by the pitching deck. A young man near the rail turns green and mocks Queequeg's tattoos between retching.

interactions.resultText: "Leave him alone," you say firmly. The young man sneers — and then is promptly knocked overboard by a swinging boom. Queequeg, without a word, dives into the freezing water and rescues him. The mocker sputters his thanks. Queequeg simply wrings out his hair and resumes watching the horizon.
The boom swings and knocks the young man overboard anyway. Queequeg dives in and saves him without hesitation. You feel a pang of shame for not having spoken up.
The ferry bumps against the Nantucket dock. You step onto the sandy shore of the whaling capital.

nantucket_ferry.chapterTitle: A Bosom Friend Goes to Sea

nantucket_arrival.title: Nantucket
nantucket_arrival.content:
Nantucket! The very name conjures visions of brave harpooners and great whales. The sandy streets are quiet but purposeful. Nearly everyone here has some connection to the whale fishery.

Queequeg's idol Yojo has advised (through Queequeg) that YOU should choose the whaling ship. The responsibility weighs on you.

interactions.buttonText: Get lodging at the Try Pots Inn
interactions.resultText: You head for Mrs. Hussey's famous establishment.

interactions.buttonText: Go directly to the docks to find a ship
interactions.resultText: No time to waste — you head straight for the waterfront.

try_pots_visit.title: The Try Pots Inn
try_pots_visit.content:
Mrs. Hussey's Try Pots Inn is marked by two enormous black pots flanking the entrance — one for clam chowder, one for cod. The smell is extraordinary.

"Clam or cod?" Mrs. Hussey demands the moment you walk in. Apparently, this is the only question that matters here.

interactions.resultText: The clam chowder is extraordinary — rich, creamy, brimming with tender clams. Mrs. Hussey beams with pride. "Best on the island, and I mean best in the world!"
The cod chowder is hearty and warming — thick with flaky white fish and potatoes. A proper Nantucket meal.

interactions.buttonText: Ask Mrs. Hussey about whaling ships
interactions.resultText: "Three ships fitting out right now," she says, ladling chowder. "The Devil-Dam, the Tit-bit, and the Pequod. The Devil-Dam's captain is young and reckless. The Tit-bit is sound but bound for the Indian Ocean. The Pequod..." She pauses. "Well, Captain Ahab is a strange one. Lost his leg to a whale. Some say it drove him mad. But the Pequod always brings back a full hold of oil."

interactions.buttonText: Rent a room for the night ($0.50)
interactions.resultText: Mrs. Hussey shows you to a clean, small room. After the Spouter Inn, it feels like luxury.
You set out toward the waterfront to find your ship.

choosing_ship.title: Choosing a Ship
choosing_ship.content:
The Nantucket docks stretch before you. Three whaling ships are fitting out for voyages:

The Devil-Dam — a newer ship with a young captain and a crew of untested men.
The Tit-bit — a reliable vessel bound for the Indian Ocean, captained by a cautious Quaker.
The Pequod — an ancient, weathered ship decorated with whale bone and ivory. Her captain, Ahab, has not been seen.

interactions.resultText: The Pequod is a sight to behold — ancient timbers blackened by decades of whale oil, her hull studded with whale teeth like a warrior's necklace. She looks like she's been through hell and survived. Her owners, Captains Peleg and Bildad, sit at a makeshift desk on the dock, signing on crew.

You approach the desk. Captain Peleg, a grizzled old whale hunter, looks you over. "Ever been to sea, lad?" You demonstrate what you know — knots, rigging, the wind. Peleg nods grudgingly. "You'll do. You'll get a 300th lay — that's your share of the profits." Captain Bildad, the Quaker, merely quotes scripture. You sign your name in the crew book.

Captain Peleg squints at you. "Ever been to sea, lad?" You stammer. He asks you to tie a bowline knot — you fumble it. "Get out of here, boy! I'm not taking some landlubber who can't tie a simple knot. Come back when you've learned something about the sea." He waves you away dismissively.

You'll need to gain some seamanship before any captain will take you on. Try working at the docks or learning from experienced sailors.

You choose the newer ship with the younger crew. The captain shakes your hand enthusiastically. But as you walk away from the Pequod, you feel a strange pull — as though destiny is trying to drag you back.

interactions.buttonText: Help the dock workers and learn sailor skills
interactions.resultText: You spend hours helping the dock crew load supplies onto the Pequod. An old salt named Bildad's nephew teaches you to tie knots — bowlines, clove hitches, sheet bends. You practice coiling rope and climbing the rigging of a beached vessel. By evening, your hands are raw but you feel like a real sailor.

Captain Peleg's face darkens. "Ahab? He's a grand, ungodly, god-like man. He's been in colleges and among the cannibals. Lost his leg to the mosbiest great white whale. Some say he's mad — but I say he's simply... Ahab." He won't say more.
You head back into town. Perhaps the Try Pots Inn or more preparation is needed.

interactions.buttonText: Mention Mrs. Hussey's recommendation of the Pequod
interactions.resultText: "Mrs. Hussey sent you, did she?" Old Peleg squints at you with new interest. "That woman knows more about whaling ships than half the captains in port. If she says the Pequod is the ship for you, I'm inclined to agree. She's never steered a man wrong." Your application gets a second, more favorable look.

devildam_ending.title: The Devil-Dam
devildam_ending.content:
You sail aboard the Devil-Dam on a three-year voyage to the Pacific. The young captain proves competent if unspectacular. You learn the whaling trade, catch several sperm whales, and return to Nantucket with a modest profit.

You never learn what became of the Pequod or Captain Ahab. Sometimes, late at night, you wonder what adventure you might have missed. The story of the White Whale — whatever it was — remains unknown to you.

— THE END —

You chose safety over destiny. Perhaps that was the wise choice... or perhaps not.

interactions.resultText: Perhaps destiny has another path for you...

signed_on.title: Signed On
signed_on.content:
Your name is in the book. You are now a member of the Pequod's crew. Queequeg signs on after you — Captain Peleg is so impressed by his harpoon skills that he offers the Polynesian an 80th lay, far more generous than yours.

As you walk away from the docks, a ragged stranger blocks your path.

interactions.resultText: The man's eyes are wild. "Ye've signed aboard the Pequod, have ye? Did they tell ye about Captain Ahab? Did they tell ye what happened to his leg?" He grips your arm. "Mark my words — that ship has a dark destiny. Ahab cares nothing for oil or profit. He hunts the White Whale — and he will drag every soul aboard into Hell with him."
You push past the ragged man. He calls after you: "Remember me when the white whale sounds! Remember old Elijah!"
It's time. You gather your gear and walk up the gangplank onto the Pequod.

interactions.buttonText: Ask Elijah what exactly he means about the Pequod
interactions.resultText: "I mean," says Elijah, leaning close enough that you can smell rum and salt, "that Ahab has been to the bottom of the sea and come back wrong. I mean that the ship's painted a color you can't wash off — the color of doom. I mean that three crews have sailed with Ahab since the White Whale took his leg, and not one man has come back the same." He grins a toothless grin. "But what do I know? I'm just a crazy old man on a dock."

boarding_pequod.title: Aboard the Pequod
boarding_pequod.content:
You step aboard the Pequod and feel the deck shift beneath your feet. The ancient timbers creak with the rhythm of the tide. Whale bones are set into the woodwork everywhere — the ship itself is like a great whale skeleton.

The crew is assembling. You see Starbuck, the first mate — tall, thin, and serious. Stubb, the second mate, puffs on his pipe with an easy grin. Flask, the third mate, is short and pugnacious.

Captain Ahab is nowhere to be seen.

interactions.resultText: Starbuck regards you with calm, honest eyes. "Welcome aboard, Ishmael. Have you whaled before?" You admit you haven't. "Then learn quickly. The sea forgives no ignorance." He pauses. "And keep your eyes open. There are... things about this voyage I don't fully understand yet."
"Hello there, greenhand!" Stubb grins around his pipe. "Don't look so nervous. Whaling's easy — you just find a whale, stab it, and try not to get killed. Simple!" He laughs heartily at his own joke.

You walk the length of the Pequod. She's old but well-maintained. The three whaleboats hang in their davits, ready for lowering. Coils of rope, harpoons, and lances are secured along the rails. At the mainmast, a bright gold coin has been nailed into the wood — a Spanish doubloon.

interactions.buttonText: Go below decks to stow your gear
interactions.resultText: You descend into the cramped quarters below.

Starbuck pauses his work. "Captain Ahab is..." He chooses his words carefully. "A great man. A great whaler. But greatness and madness share a border, and I fear our captain walks that line. He lost his leg to a white whale — Moby Dick — and he has not been the same since." Starbuck glances toward the captain's cabin. "Pray he finds what he's looking for. Pray harder that he doesn't."

interactions.buttonText: Pick up the ship's log from the navigation table
interactions.resultText: The Pequod's log sits open on the navigation table, its leather binding cracked from salt and sun. You leaf through it — previous voyages, whale sightings, coordinates. The last entry before this voyage reads: "Refitted. New ivory leg for the captain. God have mercy on us all." You tuck it under your arm.

below_decks.title: Below Decks
below_decks.content:
The crew quarters are cramped and dark, smelling of tar and old sweat. Hammocks hang in rows. You find an empty one and stow your sea bag.

Queequeg has already claimed the hammock next to yours. He's sharpening his harpoon with quiet focus. Nearby, you notice a cabinet that might contain useful supplies.

interactions.resultText: You find a detailed whale migration chart tucked between old logbooks. This could be invaluable for the voyage — it shows the seasonal patterns of sperm whales across the Pacific.

interactions.buttonText: Talk to Queequeg about the voyage
interactions.resultText: Queequeg speaks of his homeland — the island of Rokovoko, which appears on no map. He tells you of great whales in the Pacific, of his father the king, and of why he left his island to see the Christian world. "Queequeg not afraid of whale. Whale not afraid of Queequeg. We understand each other."
You climb into your hammock and let the gentle rocking of the ship carry you to sleep. Tomorrow, the voyage begins.

interactions.buttonText: Go back up to the deck
interactions.resultText: You climb the ladder back to the main deck.

ship_departs.title: Christmas Day — The Pequod Sails
ship_departs.content:
On Christmas morning, the Pequod casts off her lines and glides into the harbor. Nantucket shrinks behind you. The wind fills the sails, and the ship heels as she meets the open Atlantic.

Captain Ahab has still not appeared on deck. The crew whispers about him. Starbuck looks worried. Stubb smokes his pipe more furiously than usual.

Days pass. The Pequod rounds Cape Horn in terrible weather. And then, one dark morning, the thumping of an ivory leg is heard on the quarterdeck...

interactions.buttonText: Take a turn at the masthead watch
interactions.resultText: You climb the ratlines to the crow's nest, swaying high above the deck. The view is breathtaking — endless ocean in every direction. You scan the waves for the telltale plume of a whale's spout. Nothing yet, but the experience teaches you the art of watching.

interactions.buttonText: Learn the ropes from experienced sailors
interactions.resultText: The old hands teach you to splice rope, tie knots, and handle the sails. Flask shows you how to coil a whale line so it runs free without tangling — "a tangled line means death," he says matter-of-factly.

interactions.buttonText: Watch as Ahab finally appears on deck
interactions.resultText: The thumping grows louder. Then Captain Ahab emerges from the cabin. He is a tall, powerful man with a long white scar running down his face like a lightning bolt. Where his right leg should be, an ivory peg — carved from a sperm whale's jaw — is fitted into a special socket in the deck. His eyes burn with a terrible intensity.

interactions.buttonText: Wait for the captain to appear
interactions.resultText: Days pass but Ahab remains in his cabin. Starbuck puts you to work — there's no room for idle hands on a whaler. You scrub decks, mend sails, and learn to read the weather. "When the captain is ready," Starbuck says, "he'll appear. Until then, work."

interactions.buttonText: A sudden squall hits the ship
interactions.resultText: The sky darkens without warning. Rain lashes the deck horizontally. "All hands below!" Starbuck's voice cuts through the wind. You scramble for the hatch as the deck tilts violently, waves crashing over the bulwark. Below decks, the crew clings to hammocks and stanchions, riding out the fury.

ahab_quarterdeck.title: The Quarterdeck
ahab_quarterdeck.content:
Captain Ahab assembles the entire crew on the quarterdeck. He paces before them, his ivory leg striking the deck like a drumbeat. Then he raises a bright gold doubloon — an Ecuadorian ounce of gold.

"Whosoever of ye raises me a white-headed whale with a wrinkled brow and a crooked jaw — whosoever of ye raises me that same white whale, he shall have this gold ounce, my boys!"

The crew cheers. But Starbuck steps forward, his face troubled.

interactions.buttonText: Watch Ahab nail the doubloon to the mast
interactions.resultText: Ahab strides to the mainmast and hammers the gold doubloon into the wood with savage blows. "There! Whoever first spots the White Whale gets this coin!" The gold gleams in the sunlight — a beacon of obsession.

"Captain Ahab," Starbuck says carefully, "I came here to hunt whales, not my commander's vengeance. To pursue one whale across all the oceans — is that not madness?" Ahab's eyes blaze. "Talk not to me of blasphemy, man; I'd strike the sun if it insulted me!"
You catch Starbuck's eye and nod slightly. He returns the faintest acknowledgment. You are not the only one who fears Ahab's obsession may doom the ship.

interactions.buttonText: Join the crew in cheering for Ahab
interactions.resultText: Caught up in the moment, you raise your voice with the crew. "Death to Moby Dick!" The ritual is intoxicating — you drink grog from the harpoon sockets with the harpooners. Ahab's eyes find yours and he nods approvingly.
The die is cast. The Pequod sails on — not just hunting whales, but hunting THE whale. Moby Dick.

interactions.buttonText: Catch Ahab's cold stare directed at you
interactions.resultText: Ahab's eye fixes on you — a burning, suspicious gaze. "I know your type," he growls. "The doubters. The cowards who question whether the whale is worth the chase." He steps closer, his ivory leg clicking on the deck. "Let me be clear, boy. On this ship, there is one purpose: Moby Dick's death. Anyone who stands in the way of that purpose will wish they'd stayed ashore." The crew falls silent.
You leave the quarterdeck, Ahab's words ringing in your ears. The main deck bustles with activity — sailors coiling ropes, checking rigging, going about the endless work of keeping a ship alive.

first_whale_hunt.title: Thar She Blows!
first_whale_hunt.content:
Weeks into the voyage, the cry rings out from the masthead: "There she blows! Thar she blows!"

A pod of sperm whales surfaces a mile to starboard, their great heads breaking the water, misty spouts rising into the air. The deck erupts into controlled chaos as the whaleboats are prepared for lowering.

Starbuck commands one boat, Stubb another, Flask the third. You're assigned to Starbuck's boat.

interactions.resultText: You take your place at the oar and pull with all your might. The whaleboat shoots across the waves. Your muscles scream but you keep the rhythm. Starbuck nods approvingly from the stern.

interactions.buttonText: Use your spyglass to guide the boat
interactions.resultText: You raise your spyglass and track the whale's movements. "She's sounding! No — turning east! Fifty yards!" Your reports help Starbuck steer perfectly into position.

Queequeg rises in the bow, balanced perfectly despite the rocking boat. With a movement like flowing water, he launches his harpoon. It strikes true — the iron buries itself in the whale's flank. The line screams out of the tub. "FAST!" Starbuck shouts. "We're fast to the whale!"

interactions.buttonText: Hold on during the Nantucket sleigh-ride
interactions.resultText: The harpooned whale dives and runs, dragging your boat behind it at terrifying speed. Spray soaks everyone. The boat crashes over waves. This is the famous Nantucket sleigh-ride — and it's absolutely terrifying. After an hour, the whale tires, and Starbuck moves in for the kill with his lance.

interactions.buttonText: Hold on during the Nantucket sleigh-ride
interactions.resultText:
The whale dives and the boat lurches violently! You lose your grip and are thrown into the churning sea. The icy water hits you like a wall. You flail desperately as the whaleboat races away.

Queequeg spots you and drags you back into the boat, coughing seawater. Starbuck shakes his head. "You need more experience before you're ready for this, Ishmael. Next time, hold on tighter." The whale escapes.

interactions.buttonText: Grab a harpoon from the whaleboat rack
interactions.resultText: You lift a harpoon from the rack. It's heavier than you expected — iron head, hickory shaft, twenty-foot line coiled beneath. The head is razor-sharp, designed to bury itself in blubber and hold fast. Your arms tremble under the weight. This is the tool of the trade. This is what it means to be a whaler.
You clamber back aboard the Pequod, legs shaking from the whaleboat ride. The deck feels impossibly steady after the chaos of the hunt.

whale_hunt_recovery.title: Back on Deck — Humiliated
whale_hunt_recovery.content:
Back on the Pequod's deck, soaking wet and humiliated, you watch the other boats continue the hunt without you. Stubb catches a whale with his crew; Flask nearly gets another. You contributed nothing.

Starbuck takes you aside. "Don't hang your head, lad. Every whaleman has been thrown from a boat. But you need to be stronger, quicker. Practice with the crew. Learn the ropes — literally. The next whale won't wait for you to be ready."

interactions.buttonText: Practice climbing the rigging and balancing
interactions.resultText: You spend hours climbing the ratlines, balancing on the yards, learning to move on a pitching deck. Your muscles ache but your balance improves dramatically.

interactions.buttonText: Practice hauling ropes and boat handling
interactions.resultText: Flask drills you on rope handling — coiling, throwing, belaying. Your hands blister and bleed, but you learn. "A man who can handle a rope can handle anything at sea," Flask says with grudging approval.

interactions.buttonText: Another whale is spotted — try again!
interactions.resultText: "THERE SHE BLOWS!" The cry rings out again. This time, you're determined not to fail.

after_first_whale.title: The Try-Works
after_first_whale.content:
The dead whale is lashed alongside the ship. The brutal work of cutting-in begins — stripping the blubber in great blankets. The try-works are lit, rendering the blubber into oil. The ship becomes a factory of fire and grease.

You work through the night, your clothes soaked in oil and blood. The try-pots flame like the fires of hell against the dark ocean sky. It is terrible, magnificent work.

Your share of this whale adds to your earnings.

interactions.buttonText: Work the try-works through the night
interactions.resultText: You feed blubber into the try-pots and stir the boiling oil. The work is grueling but oddly mesmerizing. The flames cast dancing shadows across the deck. You feel yourself becoming a true whaleman.

"Not bad for your first whale, Ishmael!" Stubb grins, pipe clenched in his teeth even as oil splatters around them. "There's nothing like it in the world. The chase, the danger, the reward. Just remember — it's the everyday whales that pay the bills. Let Ahab chase his White Whale. We'll fill the hold with oil."
Days pass. More whales are taken. The Pequod pushes deeper into the Pacific.

interactions.buttonText: Head below decks for some rest
interactions.resultText: Exhausted from the hunt and the tryworks, you descend to the crew quarters. The hammocks sway gently with the ship's motion.

gam_encounter.title: The Gam
gam_encounter.content:
"Sail ho!" The lookout spots another whaler. It's the Jeroboam, a Nantucket vessel. In whaling tradition, the two ships draw alongside each other for a "gam" — an exchange of news and letters.

But the Jeroboam's captain has a warning: they encountered Moby Dick three months ago. The White Whale killed their chief mate, Mr. Macey. A fanatic aboard the Jeroboam claims the whale is the incarnation of the Archangel Gabriel.

Ahab listens with burning intensity. "Where? WHERE did you see him?"

interactions.buttonText: Listen carefully to the Jeroboam's tale
interactions.resultText: The Jeroboam's crew describes Moby Dick in terrified detail — a massive white sperm whale with a wrinkled brow, a crooked jaw, and a malevolent intelligence. He attacked their boats with calculated fury. They barely escaped with their lives.

interactions.buttonText: Share your growing concern with Starbuck
interactions.resultText: "I know," Starbuck says quietly, watching Ahab pace the deck with renewed fury. "Every ship we meet has a warning. And every warning only strengthens his resolve. We are in the grip of a madman, Ishmael. I fear for us all."

Ahab fixes you with his burning gaze. "What is it, boy? Do you fear the White Whale?" His voice drops to a whisper. "Every wave of the sea brings me closer to him. I can feel it in my bones — my whale bone leg knows its brother." There is no reasoning with this man.
The Pequod leaves the Jeroboam behind and pushes deeper into the Pacific, following the whale migration routes.

interactions.buttonText: Think of the memorial tablets in the chapel
interactions.resultText: The Jeroboam's tale chills you to the bone. You think of the memorial tablets in the Whaleman's Chapel — "killed by a sperm whale." Those weren't just names carved in marble. They were men like these, on ships like these, chasing whales like this. And now Ahab wants to chase the worst one of all.

interactions.buttonText: Examine the Jeroboam through your spyglass
interactions.resultText: You train the spyglass on the departing Jeroboam. Her hull is scarred with deep gouges — claw marks from an enormous creature. The bowsprit is shattered and jury-rigged. And there, painted over but still visible in the right light: a white shape on the stern. They've tried to paint over the image of a white whale. These men have seen Moby Dick, and they bear the scars to prove it.

interactions.buttonText: Head to the quarterdeck to confront Ahab about the Jeroboam's warning
interactions.resultText: The Jeroboam's tale weighs heavily on you. You climb to the quarterdeck to see if Ahab shows any sign of doubt. He stands at the rail, staring at the horizon, jaw clenched. No doubt. None at all.

interactions.buttonText: Go below to talk with the crew
interactions.resultText: You head below decks. The crew is restless after the gam — whispered conversations about the Jeroboam's fate and what it means for the Pequod.

crows_nest_watch.title: The Mast-Head
crows_nest_watch.content:
You take your regular turn at the masthead — climbing a hundred feet above the deck to the tiny platform at the top of the mainmast. The ship sways beneath you, and the endless blue ocean stretches to infinity.

Up here, alone with sky and sea, the mind wanders. The Pacific seems to breathe. You feel small, insignificant, yet strangely at peace.

interactions.buttonText: Scan the horizon with your spyglass
interactions.resultText: Through the brass lens, you spot something — a dark shape rolling in the swells two miles off the port beam. A whale! But what color? You strain to see... It's dark. A regular sperm whale, not the White one. You call down your sighting and the boats are lowered for another hunt.

The Pacific is so immense that all human activity seems trivial. Ships are specks, whales are fleeting shadows, and even the mighty Pequod is nothing against this wilderness of water. You think of home, of the life you left behind, and wonder if you'll ever see land again.

You study the chart and realize the Pequod's course is deviating from the normal whale hunting grounds. Ahab is steering the ship toward the equatorial Pacific — toward the exact waters where Moby Dick was last sighted. The hunt for the White Whale is overtaking the business of whaling.
You descend the ratlines and return to the bustle of the deck.

interactions.buttonText: Cross-reference the whale chart with your compass readings
interactions.resultText: You spread the whale migration chart on your knees and take compass readings. The Pequod's course doesn't match any known whaling route. According to the chart, sperm whales congregate far to the south this season. But Ahab is steering northeast — toward the Pacific equatorial grounds where Moby Dick was last sighted. This isn't a whaling voyage. It's a hunt for one specific whale.

interactions.buttonText: Climb down to the main deck
interactions.resultText: You descend from the crow's nest, the wind plucking at your coat as you navigate the ratlines. The deck is far below, busy with the rhythms of shipboard life.

typhoon_approaches.title: The Typhoon
typhoon_approaches.content:
The sky darkens. The barometer plummets. A typhoon bears down on the Pequod with terrible fury. The wind howls like a living thing, and waves as tall as the masts crash over the deck.

Saint Elmo's fire dances on the mastheads — eerie blue flames that the crew takes as an omen. Ahab stands in the storm, exhilarated, his ivory leg braced against the deck. He holds his harpoon aloft and the fire dances on its tip.

"I am a lord of the level loadstone!" he roars into the tempest.

interactions.resultText: You climb into the shrouds to lash down the sails. The wind tears at you, trying to rip you from the ropes. Rain blinds you. But you hold on, and together with the crew, you save the Pequod from losing her masts.

interactions.buttonText: Use your rope to lash yourself to the mast
interactions.resultText: You tie yourself securely to the mast with your rope. When a massive wave sweeps the deck, others are washed to the scuppers — but you hold firm. Your foresight saves you from being swept overboard.

interactions.buttonText: Check your compass against the ship's
interactions.resultText: The storm has magnetized the ship's compass — it points the wrong way! Using your personal compass, you discover the Pequod is now sailing in the wrong direction. When you report this to Starbuck, he confronts Ahab — who smashes the ship's compass and fashions a new one from a sail needle. Even nature bends to Ahab's will.
The typhoon rages for three days. When it finally passes, the Pequod is battered but intact. The crew is exhausted. And still Ahab drives the ship forward.

A monstrous wave crashes over the deck! Without a rope to hold you, you're swept off your feet and slammed against the bulwark. The sea pours over you. You manage to grab a railing, but you're dangling over the churning ocean.

Queequeg appears through the spray and hauls you back aboard with one powerful arm. "You need rope, Ishmael! Always rope in storm!" You're alive, but battered and shaken.

interactions.buttonText: Watch in horror as your sea bag washes overboard
interactions.resultText: A monstrous wave crashes over the deck. Your sea bag — lashed to the mast, you thought securely — tears free and tumbles into the black water. All your savings, gone. Every cent you earned at the docks, every coin you scraped together. Swallowed by the ocean in an instant. You stare at the churning water where your money disappeared and feel the full weight of the sea's indifference.

interactions.buttonText: Dive across the deck to save a crewman sliding overboard
interactions.resultText: A young sailor — barely more than a boy — loses his footing as the deck heaves. He slides toward the broken railing, eyes wide with terror. You don't think. You launch yourself across the wet planks, catching his wrist at the last possible second. For a horrible moment you both dangle over the churning void, then Stubb grabs your legs and hauls you back. "Brave fool!" Stubb shouts over the wind, but he's grinning.

typhoon_aftermath.title: Typhoon Aftermath
typhoon_aftermath.content:
The storm has passed but you're in bad shape — bruised, cut, and half-drowned. The ship took damage too: a mast cracked, ropes snapped, supplies washed overboard.

Starbuck organizes repair crews. There's salvageable rope tangled in the wreckage. The ship needs every hand to help with repairs before you can continue.

interactions.resultText: You untangle a good length of hemp rope from the shattered spar. It's waterlogged but strong. You coil it carefully — you won't be caught without rope again.
You work alongside the crew splicing ropes, patching sails, and reinforcing the damaged mast. It's grueling work but essential. The Pequod slowly recovers.

interactions.buttonText: Treat your injuries with the medical kit
interactions.resultText: You clean and bandage your cuts. The laudanum helps with the pain from your bruised ribs. You'll live.
With the ship patched up, the Pequod sails on. The storm has rattled the crew, but Ahab is undeterred.

starbucks_dilemma.title: Starbuck's Dilemma
starbucks_dilemma.content:
Late one night after the typhoon, Starbuck comes to find you. His face is pale. He speaks in a whisper:

"Ishmael, I've been standing at the captain's cabin door. He sleeps. His musket hangs by the door. I could... end this madness. Save the ship. Save thirty lives. One shot, and we could turn this ship toward home."

He looks at you with desperate eyes. "What should I do?"

interactions.resultText: Starbuck stares at the musket for a long moment. Then he shakes his head. "No. No, I cannot murder a sleeping man, no matter how mad he is. God forgive me." He puts the musket back. "But mark me, Ishmael — Ahab will kill us all."

interactions.buttonText: "Wait, Starbuck. There may be another way."
interactions.resultText: "What other way?" Starbuck asks bitterly. But your calm words steady him. "Perhaps I can convince the crew to demand we turn back. A vote. Not murder — but reason." He straightens. "Yes. Reason. Thank you, Ishmael."
Starbuck looks hurt, then nods. "Very well. I understand." He walks away alone into the darkness, the weight of the ship on his shoulders.

interactions.buttonText: Offer to carry a letter to his family, just in case
interactions.resultText: Starbuck pulls out a worn letter — already written, already sealed. "For my wife Mary and my boy." His eyes glisten. "If I don't survive this voyage... see that they get this." You take the letter with a solemn promise.

queequeg_coffin.title: The Life-Buoy
queequeg_coffin.content:
Queequeg falls gravely ill with a fever. He wastes away until he seems certain to die. At his request, the ship's carpenter builds him a coffin — a canoe-shaped box, in the tradition of his island.

Queequeg lies in his coffin, practicing for death, with Yojo on his breast. But then, inexplicably, he recovers. He decides it is not yet his time to die.

The empty coffin is sealed and made watertight — repurposed as the ship's life-buoy.

interactions.buttonText: Tend to Queequeg during his illness
interactions.resultText: You sit by your friend day and night, bringing him water and keeping him warm. In his delirium, he speaks of Rokovoko, of his father the king, of the great tattooed mysteries on his skin. Your devotion helps pull him back from the brink.

interactions.buttonText: Use your medical kit to treat Queequeg
interactions.resultText: You apply cool compresses and administer laudanum for his pain. Your medical supplies help ease his suffering. The ship's doctor (such as he is) nods approvingly at your ministrations.

The carpenter has done fine work — the coffin is now watertight, sealed with pitch. Queequeg has carved it with strange symbols matching his tattoos. It bobs alongside the ship, tethered by a rope. You feel an eerie premonition that this coffin will prove more important than anyone realizes.
Weeks pass. The Pequod enters the equatorial Pacific — Moby Dick's hunting grounds. The air is thick with anticipation and dread.

interactions.buttonText: Hold Queequeg's hand and listen to his whispered words
interactions.resultText: Queequeg's fingers close around yours with surprising strength. In a voice barely above a whisper, he tells you something he's never told anyone: on his home island of Rokovoko, the elders foresaw this voyage. They told him he would die far from home — but that his death would save a life. He looks at you with calm certainty. "You, Ishmael. My coffin will save you." Then he closes his eyes and sleeps.

interactions.buttonText: Go up on deck for fresh air
interactions.resultText: The sight of Queequeg in his coffin-bed is too much. You need air. You climb the ladder to the deck, where the salt wind hits your face and the horizon stretches endlessly in every direction.

approaching_moby_waters.title: The Pacific
approaching_moby_waters.content:
The Pequod sails into the equatorial Pacific — warm, calm, deceptively peaceful. But the crew knows these are the waters where Moby Dick hunts. Ahab has not slept in days. He stands at the bow, sniffing the wind like a bloodhound.

Other ships are encountered, each with stories of the White Whale. He was seen two weeks ago, heading east. One week ago, heading south. The circle is closing.

The doubloon on the mainmast gleams. Every man's eye returns to it again and again.

interactions.buttonText: Help prepare the harpoons for the final hunt
interactions.resultText: Ahab has forged a special harpoon for Moby Dick, tempered in the blood of his three harpooners. You help sharpen the regular harpoons and coil the whale lines perfectly. Every preparation could mean the difference between life and death.

interactions.buttonText: Speak with Ahab about his obsession
interactions.resultText: For once, Ahab seems almost human. "I have sailed these forty years, boy. Forty years of war against the sea. And all of it leads to this — to HIM." He stares at the horizon. "Sometimes I think... is it the whale I hunt, or something deeper? Something in myself?" Then the madness returns to his eyes. "No matter. He dies tomorrow."

interactions.buttonText: Stash away survival rations, just in case
interactions.resultText: You quietly gather hardtack and dried beef into a waterproof bundle. Call it pessimism or call it prudence — you want to be prepared for the worst.

Dawn breaks. And from the masthead comes the cry that changes everything:

"THERE SHE BLOWS! A HUMP LIKE A SNOW-HILL! IT IS MOBY DICK!"

Starbuck sits alone, writing by the light of a guttering candle. He folds the letter carefully, seals it with wax, and looks at you. "Ishmael, I trust you. If the worst happens..." He hands you the letter. "For my Mary and little boy. Promise me." His hand trembles. First Mate Starbuck, who faces whales without flinching, trembles at the thought of never seeing his family again.

interactions.buttonText: Go below to check on Queequeg
interactions.resultText: Before the final chase begins, you descend below decks one last time. Queequeg sits cross-legged in his hammock, sharpening his harpoon with calm, deliberate strokes. He looks healthy again — whatever illness nearly killed him has passed. He meets your eyes and nods. Ready.

chase_day_one.title: The Chase — First Day
chase_day_one.content:
Moby Dick surfaces a mile ahead — an impossibly vast white shape, his wrinkled brow and crooked jaw unmistakable. He is magnificent and terrible. Spouts of vapor rise from his blowhole like geysers.

Ahab roars: "Lower away! ALL boats!" Three whaleboats crash into the water. Ahab himself takes command of one, his ivory leg braced in a special cleat.

You're in Starbuck's boat. The oars bite the water. The chase is on.

interactions.buttonText: Pull the oars with everything you have
interactions.resultText: You pull until your arms burn and your lungs scream. The whaleboat shoots forward. Moby Dick's vast tail rises before you — thirty feet of white muscle. He sounds, diving deep, and the boats circle, waiting.
You grip your knife, ready to cut the whale line if it fouls. Smart — a fouled line can drag a man to his death in seconds.

interactions.buttonText: Moby Dick surfaces beneath the boats!
interactions.resultText:
The White Whale erupts from the deep directly beneath Ahab's boat, smashing it to splinters! Men fly into the air. Ahab is thrown into the sea, his ivory leg snapped clean off. The other boats rush to rescue the survivors.

Ahab is pulled from the water, raging. "My leg! The accursed whale has taken my leg AGAIN!" A new peg must be fashioned from a spare spar.

Everything you've learned about whales clicks into place. The migration charts, the Jeroboam's scars, Queequeg's harpooning technique, the old sailors' tales. Moby Dick isn't attacking randomly — he's protecting something. There, in the shadow beneath the waves: a calf. The White Whale is a mother. This changes everything. This changes nothing. Ahab won't care.

chase_day_two.title: The Chase — Second Day
chase_day_two.content:
Dawn of the second day. No one has slept. Ahab, with a fresh ivory peg hastily fitted, is at the bow before sunrise. The White Whale is spotted again — closer this time, as if he's waiting.

The boats are lowered once more. This time Moby Dick seems even more aggressive, more cunning. He circles the boats, his ancient eye fixing each man with cold intelligence.

interactions.resultText: The whale moves with terrifying intelligence. He's not fleeing — he's HUNTING them back. His movements are calculated, his attacks precise. This is no ordinary whale. You begin to understand Ahab's obsession — this creature is something beyond nature.

interactions.buttonText: Warn Starbuck — this is a trap
interactions.resultText: "I see it too," Starbuck whispers grimly. "He's leading us. But Ahab won't stop. And we can't leave our captain." He checks his lance. "Pray, Ishmael. Pray for all of us."

The White Whale surges forward and tangles the three boats together with his massive jaw, dragging them in circles. Harpoons are snapped like twigs. Men are thrown into the churning water. Queequeg dives in to save drowning sailors, his strength incredible.

Ahab's harpoon strikes true — but the line fouls around his own neck. You must act fast!

save_ahab_choice.title: A Split-Second Decision
save_ahab_choice.content:
The whale line is wrapped around Ahab's neck, dragging him toward the water. The rope is taut as iron. In seconds he'll be pulled under.

Your whaling knife could cut the line — but Moby Dick would escape. Without the line, they lose the whale. With it, Ahab dies.

interactions.buttonText: Cut the line — save Ahab's life
interactions.resultText:
You slash the line with your knife. The rope parts with a snap. Ahab falls gasping to the bottom of the boat, the whale line whipping away into the sea. Moby Dick dives and vanishes.

Ahab looks at you with fury — then grudging respect. "You saved my life, boy. But you cost me my whale." He grips his broken harpoon. "Tomorrow. Tomorrow he dies."

interactions.buttonText: Try to unwrap the line by hand
interactions.resultText: You grab the rope with bare hands and try to unwind it from Ahab's neck. The friction burns your palms raw, but you manage to loosen it just enough. Ahab wrenches free, coughing and sputtering.

For one terrible moment, you freeze. Could Ahab's death end this madness? Save the crew? But Queequeg doesn't hesitate — he grabs the line and cuts it with his own knife. Ahab is saved. But the harpooner gives you a long, unreadable look afterward.

night_before_final.title: The Night Before
night_before_final.content:
Night falls on the Pequod. Two boats have been destroyed. Several men are injured. The ship itself shows damage from Moby Dick's passing.

Starbuck makes one last plea: "Captain, turn back. We have oil enough for a profitable voyage. Your crew begs you. God begs you. Turn back."

Ahab stares at the sea. "He is out there. I can feel him. Tomorrow, we finish this."

Every soul aboard knows that tomorrow may be their last day on earth.

interactions.buttonText: Stand with Starbuck — beg Ahab to turn back
interactions.resultText: "Captain Ahab," you say, "the men are exhausted. The boats are smashed. If we continue, we risk the entire ship." Several crew members murmur agreement. But Ahab is beyond reason. "I am the Fates' lieutenant; I act under orders. Tomorrow, we hunt."
You check your gear: knife, rope, coat. You eye the coffin-lifebuoy lashed to the rail. You eat your fill at dinner and drink fresh water. If the ship goes down, you intend to survive.

interactions.buttonText: Spend the night talking with Queequeg
interactions.resultText: You and Queequeg sit on the foredeck under the stars. He tells you the meaning of the tattoos on his body — a complete map of the universe, written by a prophet of his island. "When Queequeg die," he says simply, "the map die with him. Unless someone remember." He traces a pattern on your arm. "You remember, Ishmael. You tell story."

The third dawn. The sky is red. Ahab is already at the bow. The last remaining whaleboat is prepared.

From the masthead: "THAR SHE BLOWS! Moby Dick — dead ahead!"

Dawn arrives. But Starbuck pulls you aside. "You're not ready for this, Ishmael. Two boats have been destroyed. The men going out tomorrow are the best sailors alive, and they may not come back. I need you here on the ship — help me manage the Pequod while the boats are out. Work the deck, manage the lines. That's where you'll do the most good."

He puts you to work on emergency preparations. Hard, urgent work that teaches you more about seamanship in one night than months at sea.

interactions.buttonText: Go up on deck to look at the stars
interactions.resultText: You climb to the deck. Above you, the stars blaze in the tropical sky — the same stars that guided Polynesian wayfinders, Portuguese explorers, and now this doomed whaling ship to its appointment with fate. The sea is calm. Moby Dick is out there somewhere, in the dark water, waiting.

chase_day_three.title: The Chase — Third Day
chase_day_three.content:
Moby Dick surfaces in a fury of white water. He is impossibly vast — a mountain of white flesh and malice. Old harpoons jut from his hide like broken sword hilts. His eye rolls with ancient intelligence.

Ahab stands in the last whaleboat, his special harpoon raised. "For hate's sake, I spit my last breath at thee!" he screams at the whale.

The boat rockets toward Moby Dick. The whale turns to meet it.

interactions.buttonText: Stay aboard the Pequod and watch from the rail
interactions.resultText: You watch from the ship's rail as Ahab's boat drives toward the whale. The other boats, smashed in previous days, are gone. Only one boat against the greatest whale in the ocean.

interactions.buttonText: Jump into the whaleboat — join the final chase
interactions.resultText: Against all reason, you leap into Ahab's boat. The old captain doesn't object — he barely notices. His entire being is focused on the White Whale ahead.

interactions.buttonText: Climb to the crow's nest to watch and shout warnings
interactions.resultText: You scramble up the ratlines to the masthead. From here you can see everything — the whale, the boat, the vast uncaring ocean. You shout warnings and directions down to the crew.

final_attack.title: The Final Attack
final_attack.content:
Ahab hurls his harpoon with superhuman force. It strikes Moby Dick deep in the flank. The whale screams — a sound that freezes the blood.

But the line fouls. Ahab is caught — the rope whips around his neck and he is yanked out of the boat, dragged into the sea, lashed to the whale itself. He vanishes beneath the waves in an instant.

Moby Dick, maddened with rage and pain, turns on the Pequod herself. The great whale rams the ship with his massive head. Timbers shatter. The sea rushes in.

interactions.resultText:
The ship heels over, masts crashing into the sea. Men are thrown into the water. The vortex of the sinking vessel pulls everything down — boats, oars, harpoons, men. The doubloon gleams one last time as the mainmast slips beneath the waves.

Captain Ahab is gone, dragged to his death by the whale he hated. The Pequod is gone. But you...

survival_choice.title: Into the Abyss
survival_choice.content:
The Pequod spirals down into the deep. The vortex pulls at you. All around, the sea is filled with wreckage and drowning men. You catch a glimpse of Queequeg swimming powerfully, Starbuck clinging to a spar.

And then you see it — Queequeg's coffin-lifebuoy, popping to the surface like a cork, free of the sinking ship. It bobs on the waves, empty and waiting.

interactions.resultText:
You swim with desperate strength toward the coffin. Your arms are lead, your lungs burn, but you reach it. You throw your arms over the carved wood and hold on for dear life.

The vortex subsides. The sea flattens. You are alone on the face of the Pacific.
You fight the current toward Starbuck, but the first mate slips beneath the waves before you can reach him. His hand reaches up one last time, then vanishes. You turn and swim for the coffin instead.

You swim toward your friend, but Queequeg waves you away. "Go! Coffin!" he shouts, pointing at the life-buoy. Then the current takes him. The last you see of him, he is still swimming strongly, but in the wrong direction.

adrift.title: Adrift
adrift.content:
You float on Queequeg's coffin for a day and a night. The sun beats down. The sharks circle but do not attack — the coffin seems to ward them off, as if Queequeg's strange tattoos hold some ancient protection.

You think of all that has happened. The Spouter Inn. Queequeg. Father Mapple's sermon. Ahab's obsession. The doubloon. Moby Dick.

On the second morning, a sail appears on the horizon.

interactions.buttonText: Wave your coat as a signal
interactions.resultText: You strip off your wool coat and wave it desperately above the water. The dark fabric catches the lookout's eye against the bright sea.

interactions.buttonText: Flash your spyglass in the sunlight
interactions.resultText: You angle your brass spyglass to catch the sun and flash reflected light toward the approaching ship. The bright flashes are spotted immediately.

interactions.buttonText: Wait and hope — wave with bare hands
interactions.resultText: You cling to the coffin and wave desperately with your bare hands. But on the vast ocean, a man on a tiny coffin is nearly invisible. The ship sails closer... and then veers away. It didn't see you!
You cling to the coffin and wait. The ship grows larger. It's heading toward you. You're going to live.
You cling to the coffin and wait. The ship grows larger. It's heading toward you. You're going to live.

adrift_desperate.title: Lost at Sea
adrift_desperate.content:
The ship has passed without seeing you. The vast Pacific mocks your insignificance. The sun beats down mercilessly. Your lips crack. Your tongue swells with thirst.

Another day passes. Then another. Sharks circle closer. The coffin-lifebuoy keeps you afloat, but for how long? You're dying of exposure.

Then — on the third morning — another sail! Smaller this time, a whaling bark. But she's far away and moving fast.

interactions.buttonText: Hold up Yojo — the idol catches the light
interactions.resultText:
In desperation, you hold Queequeg's polished idol above your head. Its dark surface catches the sunlight and flashes. Once, twice — a lookout on the bark spots the glint. The ship turns toward you!

Queequeg's last gift saves your life.

interactions.buttonText: Polish your knife blade and flash the sun
interactions.resultText: You rub your whaling knife on the coffin until it gleams, then angle the blade to catch the sun. The bright flash catches a lookout's eye. The bark alters course!

interactions.buttonText: Eat your survival rations and wait for another ship
interactions.resultText: The hardtack and dried beef keep you alive for three more days. On the sixth day adrift, a Portuguese whaler spots you and picks you up. You're barely alive, but you survived.
Without supplies, without a way to signal, the sea claims you as it claimed the rest of the Pequod's crew. The coffin-lifebuoy drifts on, empty, a monument to what was lost.

death_at_sea_ending.title: Lost to the Deep
death_at_sea_ending.content:
The Pacific claims another soul. You slip from the coffin-lifebuoy and sink into the dark water. The sharks close in.

No one will ever know what happened to the Pequod. No one will tell the tale of Ahab's mad hunt, of Queequeg's nobility, of Starbuck's doomed courage. The story dies with you.

Perhaps if you had been better prepared — a spyglass to signal with, a warm coat to wave, survival rations to sustain you — things would have been different.

— THE END —

You were not prepared. The sea shows no mercy to the unprepared.

interactions.buttonText: Start over — prepare better this time
interactions.resultText: The sea gives you another chance...

rescue.title: The Rachel
rescue.content:
The ship is the Rachel — a Nantucket whaler that was searching for her own captain's son, lost in a previous encounter with Moby Dick. Instead, she finds you — the sole survivor of the Pequod.

Strong arms pull you from the water. Warm blankets are wrapped around you. Hot broth is pressed into your trembling hands.

You are alive. You alone survived to tell the tale.

interactions.buttonText: Tell them everything — the whole story
interactions.resultText: You tell the crew of the Rachel everything. Ahab's obsession. The chase. The destruction. They listen in horrified silence. The captain shakes his head. "Mad. Utterly mad." But his eyes are wet.

interactions.buttonText: Ask them to deliver Starbuck's letter to his wife
interactions.resultText: You hand over the worn envelope, sealed with wax. "For Mrs. Mary Starbuck of Nantucket. From her husband. His last words." The captain takes it reverently. "It will be delivered. You have my word."
As the Rachel turns for home, you stand at the rail and watch the Pacific stretch behind you. Somewhere in those depths lie the Pequod, Captain Ahab, and Moby Dick.

final_ending.title: Epilogue — The Survivor
final_ending.content:
"And I only am escaped alone to tell thee." — Job

You return to Nantucket aboard the Rachel. The news of the Pequod's destruction spreads like wildfire. You are the only witness, the sole survivor of Ahab's mad quest.

In time, you write it all down — the voyage, the hunt, the obsession, the destruction. The world must know what happens when a man pits his will against the unconquerable forces of nature.

Queequeg. Starbuck. Stubb. Flask. Ahab. All gone. But their story lives on through you.

For you are Ishmael. And you survived.

— THE END —

interactions.buttonText: Play again — choose a different path
interactions.resultText: Perhaps the story could have gone differently...
